conclusion: To determine if objects A and B have the same velocity at time t1, analyze the acceleration-time graph.
The vertical axis represents acceleration (a), and the horizontal axis represents time (t).
The area under the acceleration-time graph gives the change in velocity over that time period.
Object A has a constant acceleration, represented by the horizontal line at a_A.
The change in velocity (Δv_A) of object A from time 0 to t1 is given by Δv_A = a_A * t1.
Object B has a linearly increasing acceleration, represented by the line starting from the origin and increasing to a_B at t2.
The change in velocity (Δv_B) of object B from time 0 to t1 is given by Δv_B = 1/2 * t1 * a_B.
At t1, object B's acceleration is half of a_B because the acceleration increases linearly. Denote this acceleration at t1 as a_{B_1} = a_B/2.
For object A: Δv_A = a_A * t1.
For object B: Δv_B = 1/2 * t1 * a_{B_1} = 1/2 * t1 * a_B/2 = a_B/4 * t1.
At t1, the velocity of object A is a_A * t1, and the velocity of object B is a_B/4 * t1.
Since the areas under the graph are not equal at t1, the velocities of objects A and B are not the same at this time.
No, at time t1, the two objects do not have the same velocity.
